column1: For purposes of this table, states were included if they mandated the listed actions. A number of states released guidance or recommendations related to the actions listed in this table but fell short of issuing a requirement and are thus not included.

For historical data, including dates of state actions, please see our [GitHub](https://github.com/KFFData/COVID-19-Data/tree/kff_master/State%20Policy%20Actions/State%20Social%20Distancing%20Actions) page.
1. The category totals for state face covering requirements may sum to more than 51 as some states may impose more than one type of requirement.

2. Beginning Aug. 11, non-residents entering Alaska from another state or country must submit a travel declaration with a negative COVID-19 test result 72 hours prior to departure, arrive with proof of a qualifying negative test, or purchase a test upon arrival and self-quarantine.
3. In California, outdoor gatherings of no more than three households are permitted.
4. In addition to employees, these states require patrons/visitors in limited sectors to wear face coverings.

5. These states did not formally issue stay at home orders; however, other actions, including closing non-essential businesses, banning large gatherings, and issuing advisories urging residents to stay home, had the same effect. For these states, rolling back such measures is listed as easing/lifting the stay at home order.
6. The gathering ban listed for these states refers to the lowest indoor limit in a majority of the state; there are higher limits for outdoor or other settings.

7. A new stay at home order, new restrictions banning gatherings of more than five peopla, and sevice limist on bars and restaurants are in place on the island O'ahu, which accounts for over 70% of Hawaii's population.
8. Travelers to Hawaii may avoid the mandatory 14-day quarantine if they register with the state and provide a negative COVID-19 test conducted within 72 hours of their arrival.

9. Illinois adopted new restrictions, limiting large gatherings to no more than 25 people and placing new limits on restaurant and bar service, in 9 counties in Region 1 to combat a resurgence of COVID-19 in those areas.
10. Large gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted.
11. Any gathering of greater than 500 people must receive approval from the local health department.
12. Iowa limits gatherings to 50% of indoor or outdoor venue capacity and requires social distancing of 6 feet; if these requirements cannot be met, gatherings are limited to 10 people.
13. Bars are closed in two counties in the state.
14. Although the Governor has recommended pausing the move to phase out of the reopening plan, all businesses have reopened and the state has delegated decisionmaking authority to the local level.
15. Maine provides exceptions to the mandatory traveler quarantine based on negative COVID test results or travel from certain states.
16. All retail businesses can reopen with capacity limits in 13 rural counties.
17. Local jurisdictions are permitted to impose tighter restrictions.
18. MA limits gatherings indoors to eight people per 1,000 square feet, not to be greater than 25 people, and gatherings outdoors to 25% of facility capacity, not to exceed 100 people.
19. Masks must be worn in school buildings and classrooms.
20. Face coverings are required in public indoor spaces and for organized outdoor activities when social distancing is not possible in counties with four or more active cases.

21. Bars in counties determined to have Elevated Disease Transmission shall close, and restaurants in those counties will revert to Phase I service limitations. County-level data are reviewed every two weeks. As of October 8, the order affects two of 16 counties in Nevada.
22. Face coverings are required for all attendees of scheduled events with greater than 100 people present.

23. NJ limits gatherings indoors to 25% of room capacity, not to be greater than 100 people or smaller than 10 people, and gatherings outdoors to 500 people. All attendees must wear face masks and maintain six feet of distance.

24. In New York, areas that have a high density of cases are subject to stricter policies, including closure of non-essential businesses, smaller caps on large gatherings, bar closures, and restaurant restrictions. As of October 7, this impacts six areas in five counties and boroughs.
25. Seven out of ten regions in NY are in Phase IV, which allows for large gatherings of up to 50 people. Gatherings are limited to 25 people in regions that remain in Phase III.

26. In North Dakota, areas of higher transmission have more restrictive measures in plase. Non-essential businesses, restaurants, and bars are subject to capacity limits. Large gathering are limited to smaller sizes.
27. There are four counties in OR that remain in phase 1 in which fewer non-essential businesses can reopen and large gatherings of more than 25 people are banned.
28. Face coverings are required in government buildings and restaurants, but local officials have the authority to mandate face coverings in other public places.
29. TN has implemented less restrictive orders that allow non-essential businesses and restaurants to reopen in 89 of the state’s 95 counties.
30. Bars may offer on-premises services at up to 50% capacity in hospital regions with low Covid-19 hospitalization rate.
31. Face masks required in counties with more than 20 COVID-19 cases.

32. Most counties are in Yellow (low level of restriction) phase with the exception of Salt Lake City which is still in the Orange phase (moderate). Thirteen counties are now in the Green (mimimal level of restriction) phase.

33. Travel without quarantine restrictions is allowed to and from the counties of New England; New York; Pennsylvania; Ohio; New Jersey; Delaware; Maryland; Washington, D.C.; Virginia; and West Virginia with 400 or fewer active cases of COVID-19 per million.
34. VA does not have a separate designation for bars, but bar areas of restaurants are closed, except for table seating.
35. Although most of the state is in Phase 2, some counties have been approved to move to Phase 3.
36. Except for counties in phase 3, bars remain closed and gatherings larger than five people are prohibited.
37. All social distancing restrictions were lifted by a WI Supreme Court ruling, not a decision by the Governor.
38. For schools providing on-site instruction, students, teachers, and school staff shall wear face coverings both indoors and outdoors where 6 feet of separation cannot be maintained.
